abstract.text: A view that displays a single image or a sequence of animated images in your interface.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Image views let you efficiently draw any image that can be specified using a
object. For example, you can use the

class to display the contents of many standard image files, such as JPEG and PNG files. You can configure image views programmatically or in your storyboard file and change the images they display at runtime. For animated images, you can also use the methods of this class to start and stop the animation and specify other animation parameters.
An image view uses its

property and the configuration of the image itself to determine how to display the image. It’s best to specify images whose dimensions match the dimensions of the image view exactly, but image views can scale your images to fit all or some of the available space. If the size of the image view itself changes, it automatically scales the image as needed.
For an image without cap insets, the presentation of the image is determined solely by the image view’s
property. The
and
modes scale the image to fit or fill the space while maintaining the image’s original aspect ratio. The

value scales the image without regard to the original aspect ratio, which can cause the image to appear distorted. Other content modes place the image at the appropriate location in the image view’s bounds without scaling it.

For a resizable image with cap insets, those insets affect the final appearance of the image. Specifically, cap insets define which parts of the image may be scaled and in which directions. You can create a resizable image that stretches using the
method of
. When using an image of this type, you typically set the image view’s content mode to
so that the image stretches in the appropriate places and fills the image view’s bounds.
For tips on how to prepare images, see
. For more information on creating resizable images with cap insets, see

content.text: Determine the final transparency of the image

inlineContent.text: Images are composited onto the image view’s background and are then composited into the rest of the window. Any transparency in the image allows the image view’s background to show through. Similarly, any further transparency in the background of the image is dependent on the transparency of the image view and the transparency of the
object it displays. When the image view and its image both have transparency, the image view uses alpha blending to combine the two.
The image is composited onto the image view’s background.
If the image view’s
property is
, the image’s pixels are composited on top of the image view’s background color and the
property of the image view is ignored.
If the image view’s
property is
, the alpha value of each pixel is multiplied by the image view’s
value, with the resulting value becoming the actual transparency value for that pixel. If the image doesn’t have an alpha channel, the alpha value of each pixel is assumed to be

It’s computationally expensive to composite the alpha channel of an image with the alpha channel of a non-opaque image view. The performance impact is further magnified if you use Core Animation shadows, because the shape of the shadow is then based on the contents of the view and must be dynamically computed. If you aren’t intentionally using the alpha channel of the image or the alpha channel of the image view, set the
property to
to improve performance. For additional optimization tips, see
An image view can store an animated image sequence and play all or part of that sequence. You specify an image sequence as an array of
objects and assign them to the
property. Once assigned, you can use the methods and properties of this class to configure the animation timing and to start and stop the animation.
You can also construct a single
object from a sequence of individual images using the
method. Doing so yields the same results as assigning the individual images to the
property.
Consider the following tips when displaying a sequence of animated images:
All images in the sequence should have the same size.
When scaling is required, the image view scales each image in the sequence separately. If the images are different sizes, scaling may not yield the results you want.
All images in the sequence should use the same content scale factor.
Make sure the
property of each image contains the same value.

Image views ignore user events by default. Normally, you use image views only to present visual content in your interface. If you want an image view to handle user interactions as well, change the value of its
property to
. After doing that, you can attach gesture recognizers or use any other event handling techniques to respond to touch events or other user-initiated events.
For more information about handling events, see
Image scaling and alpha blending are two relatively expensive operations that can impact your app’s performance. To maximize performance of your image view code, consider the following tips:
Cache scaled versions of frequently used images.

If you expect certain large images to be displayed frequently in a scaled-down thumbnail view, consider creating the scaled-down images in advance and storing them in a thumbnail cache. Doing so alleviates the need for each image view to scale them separately.
Use images whose size is close to the size of the image view.
Rather than assigning a large image to an image view, created a scaled version that matches the current size of the image view. You can also create a resizable image object using the
option, which tiles the image instead of scaling it.
Make your image view opaque whenever possible.
Unless you’re intentionally working with images that contain transparency (drawing UI elements, for example), make sure the
property of your image view is set to
. For more information about how transparency is determined, see

content.text: Debug issues with your image view

inlineContent.text: If your image view isn’t displaying what you expected, use the following tips to help diagnose the problem:
Load images using the correct method.
Use the
method of
to load images from asset catalogs or your app’s bundle. For images outside of your app’s bundle, use the
method.
Don’t use image views for custom drawing.
The
class doesn’t draw its content using the
method. Use image views only to present images. To do custom drawing involving images, subclass
directly and draw your image there.
The following table lists the attributes that you configure for image views in Interface Builder.
Attribute
Discussion
Image
The image to display. You can specify any image in your Xcode project, including standalone images and those in image assets. To set this attribute programmatically, use the
or
property.
Highlighted
The image to display when the image view is highlighted. To set this attribute programmatically, use the
or
property.
State
The initial state of the image. Use this attribute to mark the image as highlighted. To set this attribute programmatically, use the
property.

Internationalization of image views is automatic if your view displays only static images loaded from your app bundle. If you’re loading images programmatically, you’re at least partially responsible for loading the correct image.
For resources in your app bundle, you do this by specifying the name in the attributes inspector or by calling the
class method on
to obtain the localized version of each image.
For images that aren’t in your app bundle, your code must do the following:
Determine which image to load in a manner specific to your app, such as providing a localized string that contains the URL.
Load that image by passing the URL or data for the correct image to an appropriate
class method, such as
or

Screen metrics and layout may also change depending on the language and locale, particularly if the internationalized versions of your images have different dimensions. Where possible, you should try to make minimize dimension differences in internationalized versions of image resources.
For more information, see
Image views are accessible by default. The default accessibility traits for an image view are Image and User Interaction Enabled.
For more information about making iOS controls accessible, see the accessibility information in
. For general information about making your interface accessible, see
When you assign a value to an image view’s
property, it attempts to preserve the frame of the displayed image. Specifically, the class preserves the values of the
, and
properties of the view and the

property of the underlying layer. During restoration, the image view restores these values so that the image appears exactly as before. For more information about how state preservation and restoration works, see

A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.

API.
A view that displays a calendar with date-specific decorations, and provides for user selection of a single date or multiple dates.
A view that indicates there’s no content to display.
The base class for controls, which are visual elements that convey a specific action or intention in response to user interactions.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that can make a custom object eligible to participate in UIKit Dynamics.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
An object that manages image data in your app.
The image is tiled when it is resized. In other words, the interior region of the original image will be repeated to fill in the interior region of the newly resized image.
Creates and returns an animated image from an existing set of images.
Creates and returns an image object by loading the image data from the file at the specified path.
Creates and returns an image object that uses the specified image data.
Creates an image object from the specified named asset.
Creates an image object using the named image asset that’s compatible with the specified trait collection.
Returns a new version of the image with the specified cap insets and options.
The scale factor of the image.
A view that displays a single image or a sequence of animated images in your interface.

to respond when an ancestor becomes focused.

objects to use for an animation.

objects to use for an animation when the view is highlighted.

The configuration values to use when rendering the image.

Information about a symbol effect’s addition or removal.

A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
An object that manages the content for a rectangular area on the screen.
The option to scale the content to fill the size of the view. Some portion of the content may be clipped to fill the view’s bounds.
The option to scale the content to fit the size of the view by maintaining the aspect ratio. Any remaining area of the view’s bounds is transparent.
The option to scale the content to fit the size of itself by changing the aspect ratio of the content if necessary.
The view’s alpha value.
The bounds rectangle, which describes the view’s location and size in its own coordinate system.
